title: Christchurch terrorist gives evidence in NZ appeal court | ABC NEWS
description: The Australian man who shot dead 51 people at two Christchurch mosques in March 2019 has appeared in a Wellington court as he seeks to vacate his guilty pleas.  In a hearing set down for five days, the court is examining his claims that when he pleaded guilty in March 2020 to charges of murder, attempted murder and terrorism, he was incapable of making rational decisions because of the harsh conditions of his confinement.  He has filed two applications, including one asking for more time to appeal his sentence and conviction, and another seeking to vacate the guilty pleas he entered and move the matter to a trial.  Reporting by Barbara Miller, ABC News International.  ABC NEWS provides around the clock coverage of news events as they break in Australia and abroad. It's news when you want it, from Australia's most trusted news organisation. title: Roblox on notice over concerns online predators are targeting children | ABC NEWS
description: Australia’s e-safety regulator has placed Roblox under review over concerns predators are exploiting the platform to target children.  Communications Minister Anika Wells has requested an urgent meeting with the platform’s operator, as the e-safety Commission scrutinises Roblox’s compliance practice regarding children’s safety.  RMIT University’s Lisa Given the existing system of safety measures still has ‘limitations’. title: Ghislaine Maxwell will only talk if Donald Trump grants clemency, lawyer says | ABC NEWS
description: Ghislaine Maxwell, the jailed accomplice of sex predator Jeffrey Epstein, has refused to answer questions before members of the US Congress.  But Maxwell's lawyer, David Oscar Markus, says she will talk if President Donald Trump offers her clemency.  "Ms Maxwell is prepared to speak fully and honestly if granted clemency by President Trump," Mr Markus told the House of Representatives Oversight Committee.  His written statement also said Mr Trump and former president Bill Clinton were both "innocent of any wrongdoing" but only Ms Maxwell could explain why.  Democrats slammed the ploy for clemency from Maxwell, who is serving a 20-year sentence for grooming and trafficking girls for Epstein, some of whom were as young as 14.  "She is telling Donald Trump through her deposition that she is trying to buy her clemency," Democratic committee member Melanie Stansbury said. title: Why some medicines aren't listed on the PBS | The Business | ABC NEWS
description: Patients are being hit with excessive costs on a range of everyday prescription medicines because of flaws in the way Australia subsidises essential pharmaceuticals. From January, maximum script prices came down to $25 for drugs funded under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme. For patients taking private scripts not funded under the scheme, there's no relief. The pharmaceutical industry says sometimes it is not commercially viable for makers to apply for the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme subsidy. Australia's PBS was designed to cover the cost of life-saving and disease-prevention medicines and it funds more than 900 medicines across more than 5,000 brands. However, health advocates tell the ABC there are some regularly-purchased drugs that have fallen through Australia's regulatory cracks. These include a range of incontinence medicines, ear drops, eczema creams, inhalers, hormone replacement therapy and painkillers. Medicines Australia's Liz de Somer says the PBS funding system has not kept pace with scientific advances and she thinks "there are some things that we can do to the system to improve equity of access." #ABCBusiness  Subscribe: http://ab.co/1svxLVE Read more here: https://www.abc.net.au/news/2026-02-10/everyday-medicines-not-funded-under-the-pbs/106209526  ABC NEWS provides around the clock coverage of news events as they break in Australia and abroad. title: Australian dollar hits new three-year high | Finance Report | ABC NEWS
description: The Australian dollar has broken through the five-year down trend following a surge in gold, copper and silver prices, and the decline in the US dollar. As Alan Kohler explains, the good news is it will bring import prices down and may result in lower inflation. title: Christchurch shooter was 'pleased' with terrorism charge, court hears | ABC NEWS
description: A New Zealand appeal court has heard the Australian convicted over the 2019 Christchurch mosque attacks was "pleased" when he was charged with terrorism. The 35-year-old is attempting to vacate his guilty pleas, arguing he wasn't mentally fit to plead guilty to the terror offence, nor the murders of 51 people. title: Nine charged after violent clashes between protesters and police in Sydney | ABC NEWS
description: Nine people have been charged after protesters and police clashed during a demonstration at Sydney Town Hall on Monday night. The Palestine Action Group rally was held in opposition of a visit by Israeli President Isaac Herzog in the wake of the Bondi Beach terrorist attack. Demonstrators say they were victims of police brutality, while NSW Police officers insist they were assaulted by aggressors. NSW Premier Chris Minns has backed the police, saying they were put in an "impossible situation." title: Hostile parliamentary attacks were a factor in Greens Kat McNamara quitting politics | ABC NEWS
description: The resignation of Northern Territory Greens politician Kat McNamara has sparked a debate about parliamentary conduct in the NT.  McNamara quit for health reasons on Monday, with allies suggesting parliamentary attacks against her took their toll.  It comes as Nightcliff voters turn their mind to the upcoming by-election triggered by her departure. Political reporter Jack Hislop has this story for ABC News Northern Territory. title: Grace Tame criticised for leading intifada chants at Sydney protest | ABC NEWS
description: Former Australian of the Year Grace Tame has been criticised by state and federal politicians for leading chants of "globalise the intifada" at a Sydney rally against Israeli President Isaac Herzog's invitation to Australia. One Nation MP Barnaby Joyce has called for her to be stripped of her award.  Ms Tame has told the ABC that the politicians are trying to deflect from the real issues. title: Why did the French military dump tonnes of cocaine into the sea?  | The World | ABC NEWS
description: The French military has released video of it intercepting a ship carrying five tonnes of cocaine near French Polynesia. The haul is thought to be worth more than $1 billion and bound for Australia, but was dumped into the sea before the ship's crew were allowed to sail away. The President of French Polynesia has told the ABC that overcrowded prisons meant they couldn't prosecute the crew. Steve Symon is Chair of New Zealand's Ministerial Advisory Group on Transnational, Serious, Organised Crime, and said the surge in larger shipments of drugs through the Pacific is proving hard for Pacific nations to address.
